qas.question: Who was the long-serving president of the FA cup?
What year did Lord Kinnard die?
Was the cup lost during that time?

answers.text: his family kept it in their possession, out of view, until putting it up for auction in 2005
Christie's auction house on 19 May 2005 for £420,000 (£478,400 including auction fees and taxes)

qas.question: Who owned the 1895 replica before it was obsolete?
Where was the FA cup never auctioned?
Where was the Jules Rimet World Cup Trophy publicly displayed?
What year did the FA cup get moved to Manchester?

context: After being rendered obsolete by the redesign, the 1895 replica was presented in 1910 to the FA's long-serving president <a0_0><a1_0><b5_0>Lord Kinnaird<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Kinnaird died in 1923,<a1_0/> and <a2_0>his family kept it in their possession, out of view, until putting it up for auction in 2005<a2_0/>. It was duly sold at <a3_0><b7_0>Christie's auction house<b7_0/> on 19 May 2005 for £420,000 (£478,400 including auction fees and taxes)<a3_0/>. The sale price set a new world record for a piece of football memorabilia, surpassing the £254,000 paid for the Jules Rimet World Cup Trophy in 1997. The successful bidder was <a4_0><b6_0>David Gold<b6_0/><a4_0/>, the then joint chairman of Birmingham City; claiming the FA and government were doing nothing proactive to ensure the trophy remained in the country, Gold stated his purchase was motivated by wanting to save it for the nation. Accordingly, Gold presented the trophy to <b8_0>the National Football Museum<b8_0/> in Preston on 20 April <b9_0>2006<b9_0/>, where it went on immediate public display. It later moved with the museum to its new location in Manchester. In November 2012, it was ceremonially presented to Royal Engineers, after they beat Wanderers 7–1 in a charity replay of the first FA Cup final.
